item.title: Meet our Students
item.description: Meet these Computer Science and Engineering students to see what they've learned during their time at Taylor!

item.title: Links
item.description: As a student, you have free access to the complete suite of developer tools by JetBrains. Find out more here. For information on how to print a poster showcasing your project, look at this article on Poster Printing To activate Azure for students to get access to a suite of services to help you develop and deploy enterprise-grade web apps, among other things, sign in to your Taylor account here.

item.title: Poster Printing Services
item.description: THIS IS NOT THE TAYLOR PRINT SHOP. We cannot accept the discount coupons/forms that they provide. Please contact the University Press at x85218 or visit them (by the TU Post Office) if you have a coupon and need a poster printed. The CSE Dept is happy to provide large format printing for our students. We can print up to 42” wide by any length. New for 2017: We are using semi-gloss coated paper, which makes your prints look much nicer.

item.title: FAQ
item.description: FAQ How can I transfer my AP or dual credit classes? What’s a double major? Double majors are for people who are interested in studying more than one major. Taylor University allows students to declare any combination of minors and majors. Be sure that there is adequate overlap between the two majors so that you can finish in time! Also, be aware that there is a 160 credit hour cap.

item.title: COS120
item.description: COS 120 Introduction to Computational Problem Solving Approaches to computing solutions for problems from a variety of subject areas are examined and provide motivation for the study of the development of algorithms and their implementation. Programming concepts are introduced incrementally in order to solve increasingly complex problems. Good algorithm design and program structure are emphasized. Introductory data structures and software engineering principles are stressed. An introduction to object oriented programming is included.

item.title: GameJam
item.description: The TU CSE GameJam is a game jam series hosted every semester by the CSE Department and Dr. Jon Denning and run by students at Taylor University. A game jam is a short, fun, and intense party during which students get together to develop a video game from scratch. Regardless of major or knowledge of programming, all TU students are invited to participate!

item.title: Dr. Stefan Brandle
item.description: Dr. Stefan Brandle Professor and Department Co-chair of Computer Science and Engineering   What do I say? Great literature is supposed to have a catchy first line. Moby Dick begins, “Call me Ishmael.” But I’m not sure that I’m up to great literature. And my name’s not Ishmael. Should I write something profound? Something frivolous? What does one say about oneself in this sort of situation?

item.title: Systems Option
item.description: What is Systems? Systems is not a minor in Computer Science. The goal of the Systems curriculum is to help students recognize that the world is filled with systems (like educational, distribution, and manufacturing systems). It is the processes inhabiting these systems that produce value and help organizations achieve high performance. Our graduates are enjoying careers at enterprises of all sizes, including global consulting companies.   What in the world is Accenture selling?

item.title: Abet Accreditation
item.description: Our Engineering & Computer Engineering programs are ABET-accredited. Accreditation The Engineering & Computer Engineering degree programs are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET (https://www.abet.org). Program Educational Objectives Prepare our graduates to server others dependably, most importantly their employer, customers, and community. Prepare our graduates to practice technical competence, producing reliable engineering designs. Prepare our graduates to exercise creativity in their work, fostering innovative solutions.

item.title: About Us
item.description: Sometimes alumni Ashley Crutcher designs websites that convince people to buy products, like guacamole. But sometimes her goal is more serious, like convincing people to follow Jesus. At Taylor University, the Computer Science & Engineering (CSE) department is more than just a section of the science building. We have our own community on the second floor of the environmentally sustainable Euler Science Complex that flourishes as a learning environment.

item.title: Faculty
item.description: Faculty and Staff The Computer Science and Engineering faculty and staff are a group of highly qualified professionals with expertise and experiences that include software engineering, artificial intelligence, leadership in major corporations, ethics in technology, and computing standards in tax codes. They each value interaction with students both inside and outside of the classroom. The faculty and staff care about the students as mentors and friends. Their conversations can range anywhere from the classic Star Wars/Star Trek/Avengers talk to deep theology or philosophy.

item.title: TSAT
item.description: Taylor to the skies The sky’s the limit at Taylor! (Photo courtesy of NASA.) The Taylor Satellite (TSAT) is a student-developed dual Cube-Sat Unit (4 x 4 x 8 inches) nanosatellite participating in NASA’s ELANA-5 (Educational Launch of Nanosatellites). TSAT was selected by NASA in a competitive program with other universities and was the only undergraduate program chosen. TSAT is short for Taylor, Technology, and TEST – Satellite.

item.title: Activities in CSE
item.description: Activities in CSE Taylor University’s Computer Science and Engineering Department believes that the strongest Computer Scientist and Engineer is defined not only by remarkable competence, but also strong character, interpersonal skills, and leadership through service. Consequently, the CSE strives to present students with a surplus of opportunities to help them engage with the real world in strong community, while growing in their abilities. Clubs TWEET Also known as Taylor Women Engaging in Engineering and Technology, this club allows women in Taylor’s science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) to participate in fun activities together.

item.title: Feature Selection for Malware Classification
item.description:
Feature Selection for Malware Classification

Mitchell Mays Noah Drabinsky Dr. Stefan Brandle Fri, Apr 28, 2017

In applying machine learning to malware identification, different types of features have proven to be successful.
